questions.text: Pseudo-Koebner’s phenomenon is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Verruca. Pseudo-Koebner's phenomenon refers to the development of lesions in areas of trauma or friction, but in a way that is not characteristic of the typical Koebner phenomenon. In the case of verruca (warts), which are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), the lesions can appear in areas of trauma or pressure, even though the process is not strictly autoimmune. When the skin is traumatized, it can induce the development of warts, which are not part of the Koebner phenomenon seen in autoimmune diseases. This is why verruca is the correct answer. A. Psoriasis is incorrect. Psoriasis is a classic example of the Koebner phenomenon, where new psoriatic plaques can appear at sites of trauma or injury due to an autoimmune response. The Koebner phenomenon is well documented in psoriasis, but it differs from the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon seen in warts, which does not involve an autoimmune mechanism. B. Lichen planus is incorrect. Lichen planus can also exhibit the Koebner phenomenon, where new lesions develop at sites of injury or trauma. Like psoriasis, this involves an autoimmune response, so it does not fit the definition of pseudo-Koebner’s phenomenon. D. Vitiligo is incorrect. Vitiligo is associated with the Koebner phenomenon as well, where new depigmented patches of skin can appear following trauma. This is due to an autoimmune destruction of melanocytes, which is distinct from the non-autoimmune mechanism seen in verruca.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Papilloma virus infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Condyloma acuminata. Condyloma acuminata is a type of genital wart caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly types 6 and 11. HPV is a member of the Papillomaviridae family, and it is known for causing benign epithelial lesions, including warts. Condyloma acuminata typically appears in moist areas such as the genital, anal, and perianal regions. These warts are soft, fleshy, and sometimes cauliflower-shaped, and they are a hallmark of HPV infection. A. Anatomist wart is incorrect. Anatomist wart is a colloquial term for verruca vulgaris (common warts), which is also caused by a strain of HPV, specifically types 2 and 4. However, the term "anatomist wart" does not refer specifically to the HPV infection in the way that condyloma acuminata does. The term is not commonly used in clinical dermatology, and verruca vulgaris is more generally associated with HPV but not specifically categorized as a papilloma virus infection in this context. C. Condyloma lata is incorrect. Condyloma lata is a characteristic lesion of secondary syphilis, caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. These are soft, flat, and smooth lesions, usually found in moist areas such as the genital and perianal regions. Unlike condyloma acuminata, condyloma lata is not caused by a papillomavirus but by a bacterial infection, so it does not fit the description of a papilloma virus infection. D. Seborrheic wart is incorrect. Seborrheic warts, also known as seborrheic keratoses, are benign skin growths that appear with aging and are not caused by HPV. They are characterized by a scaly, often raised appearance with a "stuck-on" look. These warts are not viral in origin but rather are associated with a growth of skin cells. Therefore, they are not related to papillomavirus infection.

questions.text: Ballooning of keratinocytes is seen with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Herpes simplex virus. Ballooning of keratinocytes is a characteristic histopathological finding seen in Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections. Ballooning degeneration refers to the swelling and degeneration of keratinocytes, which become large, pale, and vacuolated due to the viral infection. This leads to the formation of intraepidermal vesicles and blisters. HSV infections typically present as painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, often around the lips (cold sores) or genital areas. A. Human papilloma virus is incorrect. While HPV causes warts and has a characteristic effect on the epidermis, it does not cause ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes. HPV infections lead to the formation of hyperplastic, thickened skin with warty growths, but the ballooning of keratinocytes is not a feature of these lesions. C. Eczema is incorrect. Eczema (or atopic dermatitis) is an inflammatory skin condition that leads to red, itchy, inflamed skin. While there may be various epidermal changes such as acanthosis (thickening) and spongiosis (intercellular edema), ballooning of keratinocytes is not typically seen in eczema. Eczema is more associated with inflammation rather than the viral-induced ballooning seen in HSV infections. D. Pemphigus is incorrect. Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder where antibodies target desmosomal proteins, leading to acantholysis (loss of cell-to-cell adhesion). The characteristic histopathological finding in pemphigus is acantholysis, not ballooning of keratinocytes. Ballooning degeneration is specifically seen in viral infections like HSV.

questions.text: Involvement of tip of nose in case of Herpes Zoster is called as :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hutchinson’s Sign. Hutchinson’s Sign refers to the involvement of the tip of the nose in Herpes Zoster (shingles) infection. When the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (V1) is affected by herpes zoster, it can result in vesicular eruptions on the tip of the nose. This is clinically significant because it suggests a higher risk of ocular involvement (such as corneal ulceration or keratitis), which can lead to vision impairment. Hutchinson's sign is an important diagnostic clue in the evaluation of herpes zoster. A. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is incorrect. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is caused by varicella-zoster virus (VZV) reactivation in the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve. It leads to a characteristic combination of facial paralysis and painful vesicular eruptions in the external ear canal or mouth. It does not involve the tip of the nose, so it is not the correct answer in this case. B. Kaposi’s Varicelliform Eruption is incorrect. Kaposi's varicelliform eruption refers to the development of widespread, vesicular lesions in individuals with pre-existing skin conditions, such as eczema or atopic dermatitis, after they are infected with the herpes simplex virus or varicella-zoster virus. This condition does not specifically relate to the involvement of the tip of the nose and is more generalized. D. Darier’s Sign is incorrect. Darier’s sign is a dermatological sign seen in urticaria pigmentosa (a form of mastocytosis) where rubbing or stroking a lesion leads to redness, swelling, and urtication (hive formation) due to the release of histamine from mast cells. It is unrelated to herpes zoster or the involvement of the tip of the nose.

questions.text: Slapped cheek appearance is characteristic of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Erythema Infectiosum. Erythema Infectiosum, also known as Fifth disease, is caused by parvovirus B19 and is characterized by the classic slapped cheek appearance. The rash initially appears on the face as bright red, erythematous patches on the cheeks, giving the appearance that the child has been slapped. This is typically followed by a lacy, erythematous rash on the body, often sparing the palms and soles. The slapped cheek appearance is a hallmark feature of erythema infectiosum. A. Roseola infantum is incorrect. Roseola is caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and typically affects children under the age of 2. It begins with a high fever followed by a pinkish-red rash that appears as the fever subsides, usually starting on the trunk and then spreading to the face and limbs. Unlike erythema infectiosum, roseola does not present with the characteristic slapped cheek appearance. C. Erythema Marginatum is incorrect. Erythema marginatum is a type of skin rash associated with rheumatic fever. It presents as well-demarcated, circular, or ring-shaped patches of erythema, often with central clearing. This rash typically appears on the trunk and limbs, but it does not present with the slapped cheek appearance seen in erythema infectiosum. D. Erythema Multiforme is incorrect. Erythema multiforme is an acute, hypersensitivity reaction that results in target-shaped lesions on the skin, often triggered by infections such as herpes simplex virus or drugs. The rash can appear on the palms, soles, and mucous membranes but does not feature the slapped cheek appearance, which is specific to erythema infectiosum.

questions.text: Which viral association is found in Pityriasis rosea-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HHV-7 Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting skin condition that has been associated with human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) and, to a lesser extent, human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6). While the exact pathophysiology is not fully understood, evidence suggests that HHV-7 reactivation may play a role in its development. This virus is known to remain latent in the body and can reactivate under certain conditions, leading to the characteristic rash of pityriasis rosea. The condition typically begins with a "herald patch," a single large lesion, followed by multiple smaller lesions in a "Christmas tree" distribution along skin tension lines. The association with HHV-7 is supported by serological studies and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) detection of HHV-7 DNA in affected individuals. Incorrect Options: (B) CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Cytomegalovirus is a member of the herpesvirus family but is not associated with pityriasis rosea. CMV primarily causes asymptomatic infections in immunocompetent individuals but can lead to mononucleosis-like symptoms or more severe complications in immunocompromised patients. It has no known role in the development of pityriasis rosea. (C) Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV): Varicella zoster virus causes chickenpox during primary infection and shingles upon reactivation. It is not linked to pityriasis rosea, as the clinical presentation and pathogenesis of VZV-related diseases are distinct. Pityriasis rosea does not involve vesicular lesions, which are a hallmark of VZV infections. (D) EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Epstein-Barr virus is most commonly associated with infectious mononucleosis and certain cancers, such as Burkitt lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma. There is no evidence to support EBV as a causative or associated factor in pityriasis rosea. In summary, HHV-7 is the most plausible viral association with pityriasis rosea based on available research, while the other options are unrelated to the condition.

questions.text: Myrmecia warts are
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Plantar wart Myrmecia warts are a specific type of plantar wart caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), specifically HPV type 1. They are commonly found on the soles of the feet and are characterized by their deep, painful lesions, often resembling a "seed wart" due to small black dots (thrombosed capillaries) on their surface. These warts tend to grow inward due to the pressure exerted while walking, making them painful and difficult to treat. The name "myrmecia" is derived from the Greek word for "ant" because of their sting-like pain. Plantar warts are distinct from other types of warts due to their location, clinical appearance, and associated discomfort. Incorrect Options: (A) Plane wart: Plane warts, also known as flat warts, are caused by HPV types 3 and 10. They are typically smooth, flat-topped, and slightly raised lesions found on the face, neck, or backs of hands, but not on the soles of the feet. These warts are painless and unrelated to the myrmecia type of wart. (C) Verrucous wart: Verrucous warts refer to warts with a rough, cauliflower-like appearance. While they can appear on various body parts, they are not synonymous with myrmecia warts. Verrucous warts are often caused by different HPV strains and are not specifically associated with the soles of the feet. (D) Palmar wart: Palmar warts occur on the palms of the hands and are also caused by HPV. However, myrmecia warts are specifically located on the soles (plantar surface) of the feet and have unique characteristics, such as deeper penetration and more pronounced pain. Palmar warts, while similar in appearance, are anatomically distinct. In summary, myrmecia warts are a subset of plantar warts with unique features that differentiate them from other wart types, making "Plantar wart" the correct answer.

questions.text: Ballooning is characteristic of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Herpes zoster Ballooning is a characteristic histopathological feature seen in infections caused by herpesviruses, including Herpes zoster (caused by varicella-zoster virus). It refers to the intracellular edema and swelling of keratinocytes in the epidermis, leading to the formation of large, swollen cells with a pale, vacuolated appearance. This process occurs due to viral replication within the cells, causing cellular damage and eventual lysis. Ballooning degeneration is typically accompanied by multinucleation, nuclear molding, and margination of chromatin, all of which are hallmark features of herpesvirus infections. Clinically, herpes zoster presents as a painful, vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution, and the vesicles contain these ballooned keratinocytes. Incorrect Options: (B) Pemphigus: Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by the formation of intraepidermal blisters due to the loss of adhesion between keratinocytes (acantholysis). While acantholysis is a defining feature of pemphigus, ballooning degeneration is not observed. Pemphigus vulgaris, for example, involves autoantibodies targeting desmogleins, leading to flaccid blisters and erosions, but it does not involve viral-induced cytopathic changes like those seen in herpes zoster. (C) Pemphigoid: Pemphigoid refers to a group of autoimmune diseases, such as bullous pemphigoid, characterized by subepidermal blister formation due to autoantibodies against components of the basement membrane (e.g., BP180 or BP230). These blisters are tense and typically involve an inflammatory infiltrate but do not exhibit ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes. (D) Insect bite: Insect bites may cause localized inflammatory reactions, including erythema, swelling, and occasionally vesicles. However, these are the result of an immune or toxic response to the insect's saliva or venom and not due to viral cytopathic effects. Histological examination of insect bite reactions does not show ballooning degeneration.

questions.text: Herpes resistant to acyclovir is treated by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Foscarnet Foscarnet is the treatment of choice for herpes infections resistant to acyclovir. Acyclovir resistance typically occurs due to mutations in the viral thymidine kinase gene, which prevents the phosphorylation of acyclovir, rendering it inactive. Foscarnet, a pyrophosphate analog, works by directly inhibiting the viral DNA polymerase without requiring activation by thymidine kinase. This makes it highly effective against acyclovir-resistant strains of herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Foscarnet is administered intravenously and is used in severe or refractory cases, particularly in immunocompromised patients. Incorrect Options: (B) Lamivudine: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) primarily used to treat HIV and hepatitis B virus infections. It has no efficacy against herpesviruses and is not used for the treatment of acyclovir-resistant HSV or VZV infections. (C) Valacyclovir: Valacyclovir is a prodrug of acyclovir with improved bioavailability. While it is effective in treating HSV and VZV infections, it shares the same mechanism of action as acyclovir, requiring phosphorylation by viral thymidine kinase for activation. Consequently, it is not effective against acyclovir-resistant herpes strains. (D) Ganciclovir: Ganciclovir is effective against cytomegalovirus (CMV) and some herpesvirus infections. However, like acyclovir, it requires phosphorylation by viral enzymes (UL97 kinase in CMV or thymidine kinase in HSV). In cases of acyclovir-resistant herpes, ganciclovir is often ineffective because the resistance mechanism (mutations in thymidine kinase) can also prevent its activation.

questions.text: HPV vaccine is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bivalent and Quadrivalent The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine is available in both bivalent and quadrivalent formulations, as well as a newer nonavalent formulation. The bivalent vaccine (Cervarix) targets two high-risk HPV types, HPV-16 and HPV-18, which are responsible for approximately 70% of cervical cancer cases. The quadrivalent vaccine (Gardasil) targets HPV-6 and HPV-11, which cause most cases of genital warts, in addition to HPV-16 and HPV-18. Both vaccines are highly effective in preventing HPV-related diseases, including cervical cancer and other anogenital cancers, and are recommended for routine immunization. The presence of both bivalent and quadrivalent options reflects efforts to provide tailored protection against specific HPV types. Incorrect Options: (A) Monovalent: A monovalent vaccine targets only one strain of a pathogen. There is no monovalent HPV vaccine available, as HPV-related diseases are caused by multiple strains, making broader coverage necessary for effective prevention. (B) Bivalent: The bivalent HPV vaccine (Cervarix) does exist, but it only provides protection against HPV-16 and HPV-18. While this is effective for reducing the risk of cervical cancer, the bivalent formulation alone does not address HPV types causing genital warts, which are covered by the quadrivalent vaccine. Thus, stating only "Bivalent" is incomplete. (C) Quadrivalent: The quadrivalent HPV vaccine (Gardasil) also exists and provides protection against HPV-6, HPV-11, HPV-16, and HPV-18. However, stating only "Quadrivalent" is incorrect because the HPV vaccine is available in both bivalent and quadrivalent formulations.

questions.text: A 24 year old woman presents with erythematous annular lesions with collarette scales predominantly arranged over trunk. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pityriasis rosea Pityriasis rosea is the most likely diagnosis for a 24-year-old woman presenting with erythematous annular lesions with collarette scales predominantly over the trunk. Pityriasis rosea typically begins with a single large lesion, known as a "herald patch," followed days later by the appearance of multiple smaller lesions in a characteristic "Christmas tree" distribution along the lines of skin cleavage. The lesions are often annular or oval, with a trailing collarette of scale located on the inner border. The condition is self-limiting and commonly occurs in young adults. Its hallmark features, including the collarette scaling and trunk distribution, strongly suggest this diagnosis. Incorrect Options: (B) Pityriasis rubra pilaris: Pityriasis rubra pilaris is a rare chronic inflammatory skin disorder that presents with erythematous plaques, follicular papules, and areas of orange-red scaling. Unlike pityriasis rosea, it often involves the palms and soles (with keratoderma) and can cause widespread erythema. The lesions are not typically annular, and collarette scaling is not a feature of pityriasis rubra pilaris. (C) Tinea versicolor: Tinea versicolor is a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species. It presents as hypopigmented, hyperpigmented, or erythematous macules with fine scaling, commonly on the chest, back, and upper arms. While it can affect the trunk, it does not typically produce the annular pattern with collarette scaling seen in pityriasis rosea. Additionally, the scales in tinea versicolor are fine and can be confirmed by potassium hydroxide (KOH) examination showing fungal elements. (D) Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with overlying silvery scales. It commonly involves extensor surfaces (e.g., elbows and knees), the scalp, and nails. Psoriatic lesions are not annular, and collarette scaling is not a feature. The distribution and appearance of psoriasis are distinct from those of pityriasis rosea.

choices.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox

questions.text: A 23 year female, primi gravida, whose nephew is staying in the same house, contracted varicella. Patient had no history of past exposure. She visited medical care centre where the varicella antibody test done and found negative?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Since patient had no history of past exposure and also the varicella antibody test was found negative,so patient can get varicella. since this will be the 1st episode of varicella,hence,patient will have chickenpox. hence,the patient is susceptible to chickenpox. after the 1st episode of chickenpox,the virus can undergo re-activation and can result in herpes zoster infection.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presents with grouped vesicles over lips as shown in image. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Impetigo is a common skin infection that most often affects young children. Bacteria including Staphylococcus aureus and Group A streptococcus cause the infection, which can lead to itchy sores and blisters,which can lead to honey colored crust. Treatment includes antibiotics. Option B-Pemphigus vulgaris presents with a flaccid blister. Option C-Varicella zoster occurs along a dermatomal distribution due to reactivation of virus. Option D-Herpes labialis presents with grouped vesicles over lips as shown in image,mostly due to HSV-1.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of papular lesions over the extremities. On examination the lesions were soft and non-tender. Image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Condylomata lata are hypopigmented, gray or white moist plaques located in the genital area in patients of syphilis. Option B-Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection that causes one or many raised, pearl-like bumps (papules) with an umbilicated center. Option C-Condyloma acuminata is a manifestation of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. The condition is characterized by skin-colored, fleshy papules in the anogenital region. Option D-Common warts are papular lesions over the extremities.The lesions are soft and non-tender,as shown in image.They are caused by HPV.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple painful blisters on an erythematous base along dermatome on trunk as shown in the image. Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Herpes simplex virus can cause blisters on lips or around mouth or genitals but it don't occur in a dermatomal distribution. Option B-Shingles/Herpes zoster presents as a grouped vesicle along a dermatome as shown in figure. Option C-The diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum is based on clinical examination. Lesions are firm, white to flesh-colored, dome-shaped, pearly papules, having a central umbilication. Option D-Chickenpox is an illness caused by the varicella-zoster virus. It brings on an itchy rash with small, fluid-filled blisters.

questions.text: Tzanck smear is used to diagnose all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-The diagnosis of herpes simplex virus may require virological confirmation. Tzanck smear is an old, rapid, cost effective but nonspecific method that has been recently re-evaluated as a method for the diagnosis of herpes virus infection.Materials obtained from a fresh vesicle were used to prepare Tzanck smears.HSV-1,HSV-2 and HHV-3,all show multinucleated giant cells on tzanck smear. Option D-Tzanck smear is not used to diagnose HIV.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple painful blisters along a dermatome on the trunk as shown in the image. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Herpes zoster/Shingles has multiple painful blisters along a dermatome due to reactivation of virus. Option B-HSV can cause vesicular lesions on genital organs. Option C-Molluscum contagiosum has dome shaped papules with umbilication. Option D-Chicken pox has vesicular lesions in multiple stages of development.

questions.text: Koebner’s phenomenon is seen in all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-The Koebner phenomenon (KP) is the appearance of new skin lesions on previously unaffected skin secondary to trauma.This phenomenon is also termed the isomorphic response, given that the new lesions appear clinically and histologically identical to the patient’s underlying cutaneous disease.True koebner phenomena is seen in psoriasis,lichen planus and vitiligo. Option D-Herpes simplex causes pseudo koebnerization,which is the appearance of new skin lesions on previously unaffected skin secondary to viral inoculation at new site.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Condyloma acuminata is a manifestation of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. The condition is characterized by skin-colored, fleshy papules in the anogenital region. Option B-Bowen disease is carcinoma in situ on penis. Option C-Condylomata lata refers to a benign and painless cutaneous manifestation of syphilis They are hypopigmented, gray or white moist plaques located in the genital area, inner thighs, axillae, or within the oral mucosa. Option D-Hemorrhoids looks reddish to bluish in colour,protruding from anal canal.

questions.text: A child presents with dome shaped, pearly lesions on forehead. Mother also having similar lesions. The likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Scabies causes burrowing lesions on finger webs and wrist. Option B-PEARLY SHINY DOME SHAPED PAPULE WITH UMBILICATION IN THE CENTER INDICATES MOLLUSCUM CONTAGIOSUM i.e, POX VIRUS. Option C-Herpes presents with grouped vesicles. Option D-HPV can present with wart like lesions in genital area.

questions.text: A child presents with the following palmar skin lesions. He also has lip lesions. Which of the following organism is the causative agent:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given image shows Target lesion which are pathognomic of erythema multiforme.they have 3 zones i.e,Dusky center,Edema (middle) and Erythema (periphery).The Most common infective/causative agent of EM is HSV TYPE 1 > MYCOPLASMA. Option B-Variant of picornavirus do not cause target lesions. Option C-Varicella Zoster virus causes eruption of grouped vesicles along a dermatome. Option D-The Most common infective/causative agent of EM is HSV TYPE 1 > MYCOPLASMA.

questions.text: A patient comes with painful vesicles on genitals. The histopathology finding will be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-painful vesicles on genitals are seen in HSV-2.The Tzanck smear will show presence of multinucleated giant cells. Option B-Pund cells are seen in donovanosis. Option C-Henderson Peterson bodies is a feature of molluscum contagiosum. Option D-Koilocytes are seen in human papilloma virus.

questions.text: All the following infections present with maculopapular rash except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B,D-Dengue (during febrile phase),Rubella and measles all can present with maculopapular rash. Option C-Shingles is another name for herpes zoster.It shows grouped vesicular lesions on the background of erythema over a single dermatome.It is a painful condition.It never presents with macule or papule.Shingles occur 2° to VZV.

questions.text: A patient came with vesicular lesions over single dermatome over the chest, he also complaints of pain. diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Herpes zoster presents with painful Grouped vesicles over single dermatome over the chest. Option B- lichen planus often appears as purple, itchy, flat bumps that develop over several weeks. In the mouth and genital mucosa, lichen planus forms lacy white patches.

questions.text: An old man presented with polymorphic lesions in Dermatomal distribution. He complaints of spider crawling sensation at night on the affected area
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-ACD (Allergic contact dermatitis) is a form of contact dermatitis that is the manifestation of an allergic response caused by contact with a substance.It presents with itching and oozing. Option B-Irritant contact dermatitis (ICD) is caused by repeated exposure to substances that aggravate the skin. Common examples of such substances are water (such as in repeated hand washing), soaps and detergents, acidic substances, solvents and other industrial chemicals. Option C-Chickenpox is an illness caused by the varicella-zoster virus. It brings on an itchy rash with small, fluid-filled blisters. Option D-Grouped vesicles along a Dermatomal distribution with spider crawling sensation at night on the affected area indicates herpes zoster.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple dome shapped lesions. The classical histopathology finding
questions.solution: Correct Answer(A)

questions.text: Vesicular rash as shown in image. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given image shows vesicular lesions on hand,foot and mouth.Hence,It is a case of Hand, foot and mouth disease caused by Coxsackie A16 virus. Option B-Roseola is a common infection that usually affects children by age 2. It's caused by a virus that spreads from person to person. It can cause a high fever followed by a rash that doesn't itch. Option C,D-Dengue and zika causes petechial rash.

questions.text: A Young HIV patient with lesions over genitals with h/o contact with CSW. What is the microscopic finding shown in the given below image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is a case of Molluscum contagiosum which shows henderson peterson bodies on microscopy,which is an Intracytoplasmic inclusion body. Option B-Intranuclear inclusion is seen in herpes viruses. Option C-Bacteria with bipolar staining is seen in donovanosis. Option D-Multinucleate giant cells is seen in HSV.

choices.text: Christmas tree appearance of Pityriasis rosea

questions.text: A patient with following itchy scaly skin lesion. what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer(A)

questions.text: A young male presented with itchy rash on the trunk as shown in the image, Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is an image of Christmas tree appearance of rash which is seen in Pityriasis Rosea. Option B-Wickham's striae are white lacy lesions seen in Lichen planus. Option C-The Woronoff ring is a ring-like hypopigmentation zone around regressing psoriasis lesions. Option D-Shingles is characterised by vesicular lesions in a Dermatomal distribution.
